displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: Tipping should be optional and not expected. Getting extra money for doing a job you were hired to do is absurd. Tips should only be given in cases of stellar service.

displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: Many view U.S. tipping culture as over-expected and coercive, with strong frustration over “tip creep,” especially tablet prompts and requests where little or no service is provided.
  • Compensation model: Around 70–75% favor shifting responsibility to employers—paying a livable base wage or abolishing reliance on tips. Several cite European-style models, integrating service into prices or adding a modest service charge.
  • Optional and merit-based: About 60–65% want tipping to be optional and tied to service quality, not mandatory or implied before service is rendered.
  • Abolish vs. reform: Roughly 30–40% explicitly support abolishing tipping altogether; others prefer reform, such as a compulsory service charge (e.g., 10%) with tips truly optional.
  • Point-of-sale concerns: About 30–40% criticize POS systems that default to tipping, want clearer “no tip” options, and recommend prompting only after clear service is provided.
  • Minority pro-tipping views: About 10–20% advocate for stronger tipping norms, higher or standardized tips (including fixed-dollar tips), or even compelled tipping due to low wages.
  • Additional ideas: Standardize tipping guidance to prevent manipulation; tip after rating service; consider tax relief on tips; offer small acknowledgments (thank-you notes/coupons) when tips are given.

Bottom line: The prevailing preference is to reduce pressure, ensure workers earn a fair wage without relying on tips, and make tipping a genuine, post-service reward for good or exceptional service rather than an obligation.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment: Most commenters view tipping culture as out of control and overly pressurized, especially with tablet prompts and requests in counter-service or pickup contexts. Many still tip regularly but dislike feeling obligated or being asked before service is delivered.

  • Pay and responsibility: A strong theme is that employers should pay a fair, livable base wage (at least minimum wage for tipped workers), so tips become a true bonus rather than a necessity. Many would abolish tipping entirely or replace it with higher menu prices or a built-in service charge. Some prefer keeping tips but only as optional and tied to excellent service.

  • Where tipping is appropriate: Broad agreement that tipping should primarily apply to full-service restaurants and delivery. Many oppose tipping for simple transactions (coffee, pickup, retail counters) or when customers serve themselves.

  • How to improve the system:

  • Reduce pressure and manipulation: make “no tip” easy to find, don’t prompt before service, and avoid default high suggested percentages.
  • Tie tips to service quality and make them clearly optional.
  • Consider alternatives: integrate service charges (e.g., 10%) into bills with tips optional; raise wages and eliminate tipping; adopt European/Japanese-style norms; limit who is tipped; reduce or remove taxes on tips; employer contributions or matching to stabilize income.

  • Clarify norms: limit tipping requests to contexts with clear, provided service; potentially reserve tipping for complex orders; reduce suggested tip rates; present less intrusive prompts.

  • Minority/pro-tipping views: A smaller share strongly supports tipping as an incentive, sometimes advocating high or even mandatory tips (e.g., 20–30%) unless wages meet a threshold. A few propose standardizing tips (fixed dollar amounts) or expanding tipping as a general gesture of appreciation.

  • Common ground: Tips, if used, should reward good service rather than compensate for low wages; customers want transparency, choice, and less social pressure; and workers should have predictable, fair income without relying on customer generosity.
